item.title: My First 5 Minutes On A Server; Or, Essential Security for Linux Servers | Bryan Kennedy
item.dc:creator: dttocs
item.description:
Any seasoned sysadmin can tell you that as you grow and add more servers & developers, user administration inevitably becomes a burden. Maintaining conventional access grants in the environment of a fast growing startup is an uphill battle - youâre bound to end up with stale passwords, abandoned intern accounts, and a myriad of âI have sudo access to Server A, but not Server Bâ issues. There are account sync tools to help mitigate this pain, but IMHO the incremental benefit isnât worth the time nor the security downsides. Simplicity is the heart of good security.
Our servers are configured with two accounts: root and deploy. The deploy user has sudo access via an arbitrarily long password and is the account that developers log into. Developers log in with their public keys, not passwords, so administration is as simple as keeping the authorized_keys file up-to-date across servers. Root login over ssh is disabled, and the deploy user can only log in from our office IP block.
item.dc:subject: linux security

item.title: CallingVault
item.dc:creator: josephschmitt
item.description:
from Daring Fireball
Great new service, sort of like Google Voice but private. CallingVault provides you with a new phone number that you have complete control over. You get call forwarding, SMS, voice mail, etc. â but the main appeal is that you get the freedom to give this number out to just about anyone and everyone, because CallingVault gives you the ability to filter and block calls from unwanted numbers. Like most of you, my only phone today is my mobile phone, and I never feel comfortable using that number when, for example, ordering products online. CallingVault provides you with a number you can distribute freely.
The website is great too, really well designed. Plans start at just $3.25/month â cheap.
Â â Â
item.dc:subject: ifttt daringfireball

item.title: 10 Super Useful Free Icon Font Sets | Freebies
item.dc:creator: digimindshare
item.description:
Advertise here with BSA
Icon fonts are great because, as you may have guessed, they are delivered as a font. This gives them a number of advantages over traditional image icons. For instance, if you want to change the color, it can easily be done with CSS. Whereas with an image, you would need to have a separate version of the icon. Scaling and adding effects, such as shadows, is just as simple.
For todayâs post, weâve rounded up 10 super useful sets of free icon fonts. Youâll find that these can be invaluable for your interface and web design projects.
Batch.
Sosa
Metro UI
Elusive Icons
Iconic Icon Set
Entypo
Ligature
Font Awesome
Typicons
Maki
item.dc:subject: from_reader_feed

item.title: Because Of Steve Jobs's First Public iPhone Call, Starbucks Still Gets Orders For 4,000 Lattes | Fast Company
item.dc:creator: digimindshare
item.description:
When he introduced the iPhone six years ago, Steve Jobs called an area Starbucks and jokingly ordered "4,000 lattes to go."
Now Fast Company reports that the same Starbucks is still seeing the same prank order to this day.
Fast Company even tracked down the Starbucks employee who took that fated original call from Jobs.
Head over to the site to see its interview with her >
Please follow SAI on Twitter and Facebook.
Join the conversation about this story Â»
